fields.name: Starry Night
fields.description: One of his most famous paintings, Starry Night depicts a swirling night sky over a sleepy town. The dramatic, vibrant colors and dynamic brushstrokes convey emotion and movement, making this piece a symbol of van Gogh's expressionist style.

fields.name: Sunflowers
fields.description: Van Gogh created several versions of his Sunflowers series, where he painted bright yellow sunflowers in a vase. These paintings are known for their bold color and energetic brushwork. The Sunflowers series is a symbol of warmth and vitality.

fields.name: The Bedroom
fields.description: This painting shows a simple room with a bed, chairs, and personal belongings. It’s famous for its use of bold, flat color and perspective, as well as for van Gogh’s focus on simplicity and comfort.

fields.name: The Starry Night Over the Rhône
fields.description: A stunning depiction of the Rhône River at night, this piece features reflections of the stars in the water. It captures the peacefulness of the night while still conveying van Gogh's characteristic intensity and emotion through color.

fields.name: The Basket of Apples
fields.description: This still life is one of Cézanne's most iconic works. It features a basket of apples, along with other objects like a bottle and a plate. The painting is famous for its complex arrangement of shapes and his innovative use of color and perspective, which laid the foundation for Cubism.

fields.name: Mont Sainte-Victoire
fields.description: Cézanne painted this mountain in southern France numerous times, each time from a different angle or perspective. His repeated studies of Mont Sainte-Victoire helped him experiment with the idea of structure and form in the landscape, making it one of his signature subjects.

fields.name: Still Life with Compote and Glass
fields.description: Another example of Cézanne’s revolutionary approach to still life, this piece is noted for the way he built depth and space through simple geometric shapes. The placement and colors of the objects draw attention to the relationship between them.

fields.name: The Card Players
fields.description: One of Cézanne's most famous works, The Card Players is part of a series he painted of peasants playing cards. The figures are solidly constructed, with careful attention to the geometric forms of their bodies and the surrounding objects. It conveys a sense of stillness and concentration.

fields.name: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
fields.description: Perhaps Seurat’s most famous work, A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte is a large-scale painting depicting Parisians enjoying a leisurely day on the banks of the River Seine. The painting is made up of tiny dots (Pointillism) and is celebrated for its meticulous technique and the innovative way it captures light and shadow.

fields.name: The Circus
fields.description: One of Seurat’s final works, The Circus features a lively, dynamic scene of performers and animals in a circus setting. The painting uses Pointillism to create the movement and energy of the performance, with bright, lively colors reflecting the excitement of the scene.

fields.name: Le Chahut
fields.description: Le Chahut is an energetic, colorful painting of dancers and musicians performing in a lively scene. The use of Pointillism creates a sense of movement, and the dynamic shapes suggest the rhythm and excitement of the performance. This work explores the contrasts of color and light within a lively, urban environment.

fields.name: The Bridge at Courbevoie
fields.description: This painting depicts a bridge over the Seine in Courbevoie, a suburb of Paris. It uses the Pointillist technique to create a shimmering effect of light reflecting off the water and the bridge. Seurat captures the quiet beauty of the scene with a restrained, harmonious use of color.

fields.name: Tahitian Women on the Beach
fields.description: Painted during Gauguin’s time in Tahiti, this work shows two Tahitian women on a beach, sitting in a relaxed and contemplative pose. The bright, tropical colors and the simplification of form are hallmarks of Gauguin's approach, emphasizing mood and spirituality over realism.

fields.name: The White Horse
fields.description: This painting shows a symbolic scene of a white horse standing in a rural landscape. It has a dreamlike quality, with simplified forms and vibrant colors that speak to Gauguin's evolving style as he moved away from traditional realism.

fields.name: The Market Woman
fields.description: This piece shows a woman from Tahiti carrying a basket, captured in bold colors with a focus on simplicity and form. Gauguin’s flattening of space and rejection of realistic detail in favor of symbolic representation is evident here.

fields.name: At the Moulin Rouge
fields.description: One of Toulouse-Lautrec's most iconic works, this painting captures a lively scene from the famous Parisian nightclub, the Moulin Rouge. The composition includes dancers, performers, and patrons, all rendered in his signature style of bold colors and simplified forms. The use of light and shadow brings energy to the scene, showcasing Lautrec's ability to capture the vibrancy of Parisian nightlife.

fields.name: La Goulue at the Moulin Rouge
fields.description: This painting features the famous can-can dancer La Goulue, one of the stars of the Moulin Rouge, in mid-dance. Lautrec’s use of bright colors and dynamic composition captures the movement and excitement of the performance. La Goulue, dressed in a brightly colored costume, is surrounded by an enthusiastic crowd, showcasing the lively atmosphere of the cabaret.

fields.name: Jane Avril at the Jardin de Paris
fields.description: Toulouse-Lautrec’s portrait of the dancer Jane Avril shows her performing at the Jardin de Paris. Known for her graceful yet eccentric dance style, Avril is depicted in an exaggerated pose that emphasizes her movement. Lautrec’s use of elongated forms and bold, flowing lines captures her energy and grace.

fields.name: The Clowness Cha-U-Kao
fields.description: This portrait of the performer Cha-U-Kao, a popular clown at the time, captures her in a dramatic, theatrical pose. The painting highlights Lautrec’s ability to capture not just the physical features of his subjects but also the personality and emotions behind the performance. The bold colors and stylized forms add to the theatricality of the piece.
